data.title: Sylvia Anderson
data.meta_description: A British actress, writer and producer best-known for her work alongside then husband Gerry Anderson on puppet shows including Stingray (1964-1965), Thunderbirds (1965-1966) and Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons (1967-1968). Sylvia Anderson was involved in all aspects of the shows she co-created, from penning storylines and designing costumes, to directing dialogue and performing voices herself, including Thunderbirds’ iconic Lady Penelope.
data.text:
BAFTA Guru

BAFTA Guru is BAFTA’s content hub for career starters packed full of inspirational videos, podcasts and interviews. Whether you’ve taken your first steps in the industry or are just starting out, you’ll find plenty here to motivate and help you along the way.

Find out more

BAFTA Kids

BAFTA’s destination for youngsters to come and discover the magical worlds of film, television and games. Enter challenges, watch videos, and take part in our annual vote to decide the best film, TV show and game of the year.

Find out more

BAFTA Young Game Designers

YGD is a gaming initiative for 10-18 year olds which explores how games are made and the skill required to make them through workshops, a video series and an annual competition.

Find out more

BAFTA 195 Piccadilly

Situated in the heart of London's West End, BAFTA 195 Piccadilly is the home of BAFTA worldwide, as well as an award-winning venue for hire that offers outstanding hospitality and a suite of flexible event spaces, which can be crafted to suit any occasion.

Find out more

A British actress, writer and producer best-known for her work alongside then husband Gerry Anderson on puppet shows including Stingray (1964-1965), Thunderbirds (1965-1966) and Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons (1967-1968). Sylvia Anderson was involved in all aspects of the shows she co-created, from penning storylines and designing costumes, to directing dialogue and performing voices herself, including Thunderbirds’ iconic Lady Penelope.

Read Sylvia Anderson's Guardian obituary here
